Award.AwardTitle: Mathematical Theory of Peridynamics and Nonlocal Models
Award.AbstractNarration:
Mengesha
1312809

The principal investigator and his colleague study the mathematical properties of nonlocal models, particularly the peridynamic model of continuum mechanics. The project focuses on establishing the well-posedness of both linear and nonlinear models for dynamic and equilibrium problems involving nonlocal boundary (volume-constrained) value conditions; classifying emerging discontinuities and developing a regularity theory for solutions of nonlocal models as functions of given data; and studying conditions that enable nucleation and propagation of singularities in peridynamic equations and other nonlocal models. The investigators use analytical tools ranging from perturbation methods to calculus of variations. The project addresses technical challenges that are absent from the traditional local approach, leading to extensions of classical mathematical concepts and techniques to the nonlocal setting.

The project offers a mathematical framework for studying nonlocal operators and equations that may be useful to the study of many common nonlocal phenomena. It helps establish the necessary theoretical footing for nonlocal models. The project findings are integrated by the investigators into classroom teaching and other educational endeavors. The investigators' long-term goal is to work with mechanical engineers, physicists, biologists and materials scientists to make nonlocal models useful tools for studying complex systems in various scientific and engineering applications such as anomalous diffusion, nonlocal heat conduction, phase transition, and biological aggregation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main objective of the proposed project was to develop a rigorous mathematical framework to a new model, called peridynamics, that is used in the mechanical engineering community to describe singular and discontinuous phenomena in materials behavior when deformed.  The research project was set to address questions related to the existence and uniqueness of solutions, the mathematical description of properties of the solutions and the development of mathematical theory that allows proper computational approximation of solutions to model problems.

A number of progress have been made. Establishing the well posedness of peridynamic model under various constraints, proper application of variational methods to the model, asymptotic analysis of solutions of static and dynamic model equations, and the develoment of the functional analytic tools for the numerical approximation of solutions are notable findings of the project. The results of the research project are reported in 9 (nine) research articles that are published in peer-reviewed publication journal. 

The project has also helped broaden the knowledge base of the mathematical and numerical study of nonlocal operators and models. The project result on the variational limit of nonlocal energy functions in the small strain theory as a function of nonlocality (published in the journal of nonlinearity) is the first of its kind to incorporate a variety of volumetric constrains. The tools developed in this and other activities of the project have also ushered the development of new numerical schemes that are being used in solving nonlocal problems. The recent work of Xiaochuan Tian and Qiang Du (SIAM J. Numer. Anal. Vol. 53,No. 2, pp 762-781) on "Nonconforming discontinuous Galerikin Methods for nonlocal variational problems” uses mathematical tools developed through the activities of the project. 

The project has also provided support and opportunity for several graduate students as well as junior researchers to participate in the research activities of the project. One graduate student, who worked on a topic of the project, has graduated with a Master of Science degree in Mathematics and is currently an assistant professor in a community college. Another graduate student who is still studying towards a Ph. D. degree in Mathematics has worked on another topic of the research project. Two postdoctoral researchers as well as visiting graduate students have also participated in the research. This opportunity surely will inspire and encourage junior scientists and early career researchers and contribute towards the development of the next generation of researchers in the mathematics of materials science.  Given that three of the graduate students were women, this NSF supported proposal will have broader impact towards NSF’s goal of full participation of women, persons with disabilities and under-represented minorities in STEM.
